question: True or False: Emotional intelligence is the ability to be aware of our own emotions and those of others, in the moment, and use that information to manage and control others.

question: There are four premises in our approach to emotional intelligence. They are (select all that apply):
answers: People can develop more emotional awareness and greater ability to manage their emotions.
All factors being equal, people with greater awareness of and control over their emotions are more successful than people who discount their emotions.
We are hard-wired to respond to the world emotionally first, and cognitively second.

question: Jorge is a manager but is required to work closely with other managers in his day-to-day tasks. He also grew up in culture that encouraged arguing – he who is loudest usually wins. His background is in managing construction projects and his forceful blunt style was appreciated, but has recently moved to a design firm, where the iterative nature of the work requires more flexibility, team integration and negotiation than he is used to. How would you encourage Jorge to build his EQ and fit in with his new team as they build a new initiative?
answers: Create a working brainstorming session with representatives from the impacted parties, ensure everyone’s voice is heard and evaluate each idea on its merits as far as efficiency and quality and have each representative approve the path forward only after any fatal flaws or points of disagreement are negotiated.

question: True or false: In a VUCA, volatile, uncertain, complex, and ambiguous world, EQ is everything and employers are placing more and more value on emotional intelligence for hiring and promoting employees.
Self-awareness does not include:
answers: Judging and punishing ourselves for our mistakes.

question: True or false: The more self-aware you are, the more in tune you become with your emotions and reactions allowing you to self-manage your responses.
Someone with a greater sense of self-awareness does the following things (select all that apply):
answers: Are able to observe self in situations, particularly difficult or stressful situations and make choices in the moment.

question: Choose the best answer: You call your sister for a quick chat. In this assignment, you’ll reflect on what you learned in this module and how you can apply it in your personal and professional life. Write a short response (250–400 words) that addresses the following questions: What did you take away from the self-regulation module and the exercises? What did you learn about yourself and others? What did you learn about your cognitive distortions and how thoughts affect feelings? How will you use the pause technique? How will you manage stress moving forward? Please be thoughtful and honest in your reflection. Your responses will be reviewed by Coursera’s AI-assisted evaluation, which will provide you with personalized feedback.
answers: In this module on self-regulation, I learned that managing emotions is not about suppressing them, but about acknowledging them and choosing a thoughtful response instead of reacting impulsively. The exercises helped me recognize how often stress or frustration can influence my decisions, and how important it is to create space between my feelings and my actions. I realized that self-regulation is a skill that can be practiced daily, especially in moments of tension. One important takeaway was the role of cognitive distortions—how my thoughts can sometimes exaggerate situations and fuel negative emotions. For example, I noticed that I tend to overgeneralize when something goes wrong, thinking “this always happens to me.” Recognizing these patterns helped me see that my thoughts directly affect my mood and behavior. By reframing them, I can shift my perspective and reduce unnecessary stress. Through the module, I also learned more about others. Everyone has their own emotional triggers, and when someone reacts strongly, it is not always about me—it may reflect their own stress or distortions. This insight encourages me to respond with empathy instead of defensiveness, which can improve both personal and professional relationships. The pause technique stood out as a practical strategy I can apply right away. Taking a moment to breathe and reflect before reacting gives me the opportunity to choose a calmer, more constructive response. I plan to use this technique in meetings or difficult conversations, where emotions can easily run high. Moving forward, I will manage stress by combining the pause technique with healthier habits like journaling, physical exercise, and setting boundaries. By practicing self-regulation consistently, I hope to increase resilience, maintain stronger relationships, and make better decisions under pressure. This module reminded me that emotional control is not fixed—it is something I can actively develop.

question: Empathy is the ability to recognize emotions and to share perspectives with others. It is one of the five key components of emotional intelligence, and it helps to build trust and strengthen relationships. In this assignment, you will reflect on how you can practice and build empathy in your daily life. Write a response (300–400 words) addressing the following: Three Stages of Empathy: Reflect on a recent interaction (at work, school, or personal life). How could you have applied cognitive empathy, emotional empathy, and compassionate empathy? Practicing Empathy: Which empathy practices (e.g., “walking in their shoes,” assuming positive intent, listening better) would have helped you understand the other person more fully? Application in Teams: How can empathy improve collaboration, performance, or well-being in your team or organization? Personal Growth: What specific step will you take this week to strengthen your empathy skills? Your response will be reviewed by Coursera’s AI-assisted evaluation, which will provide feedback on how well you applied course concepts and reflected on personal practice.
answers: Recently, I had an interaction with a colleague who seemed unusually quiet during a group discussion. Looking back, I realize it was an opportunity to apply the three stages of empathy more effectively. With cognitive empathy, I could have taken time to understand their perspective by asking myself what pressures or challenges they might be facing. With emotional empathy, I could have tuned into their feelings—recognizing the signs of stress or discomfort and acknowledging them. Finally, with compassionate empathy, I could have gone beyond recognition and offered practical support, such as checking in privately to see how they were doing and offering help if needed. When I reflect on empathy practices, I see that “walking in their shoes” and assuming positive intent would have been especially valuable. Instead of interpreting their quietness as disengagement, I could have reminded myself that there may be personal or professional reasons behind their behavior. Listening better, both to words and nonverbal cues, would also have deepened my understanding. These practices would have helped me connect with the person more authentically and reduced the chance of making assumptions. In a team or organizational setting, empathy plays a powerful role. When team members feel heard and understood, trust increases, and collaboration becomes more effective. Empathy helps reduce conflicts, as people are less likely to judge and more willing to support each other. It also contributes to well-being, since employees feel valued not only for their skills but also for who they are as individuals. This can translate into higher engagement, better performance, and a healthier work culture. For my personal growth, I will take a concrete step this week by practicing active listening during one-on-one conversations. Instead of preparing my response while the other person is speaking, I will focus fully on their words, emotions, and body language. Afterward, I will reflect back what I understood to ensure I truly captured their perspective. This small but intentional practice will help me strengthen my empathy skills and make my interactions more meaningful, both personally and professionally.

question: Before you can solve a problem, you need to define it clearly, understand your role in it, and turn it into a goal you can act on. answers: A. 6Ws (Problem Identification) In my project team, we are experiencing delays in submitting weekly progress reports. The issue involves three members who often miss the Friday 5 p.m. deadline, causing confusion for our manager on Monday mornings. The reports are submitted through our shared Google Drive folder, but files are often incomplete or incorrectly named. This problem started two weeks ago when workload increased, and it happens mostly at the end of the week. The reason is that team members are prioritizing urgent tasks over reporting, and no one is double-checking submissions. As a result, the manager spends extra time following up, which delays decision-making. The process currently lacks accountability and a clear reminder system. The problem is important because timely, accurate reporting is necessary for tracking progress and meeting our client’s expectations. B. My Role I am responsible for consolidating the reports and ensuring they are ready for the manager by Monday. However, I often receive late or incomplete files, which prevents me from finishing my task on time. I contribute to the problem because I have not set clear file-naming standards or sent reminders before the deadline. My constraints are that I cannot change team members’ workload priorities, but I can improve communication, create a checklist, and send automated reminders. My assumption is that if expectations are clearer and reminders are timely, team members will submit more consistently. C. Goal-Oriented Question How might I create a clear reporting process with reminders and standards for my team so that all progress reports are complete and submitted by Friday 5 p.m. for on-time consolidation within the next four weeks?

question: In Module 1, you reframed your problem into a goal-oriented question. Now you’ll practice brainstorming, categorizing, and evaluating possible solutions. Step 1. Share your reframed goal-oriented question. Step 2. Brainstorm solutions. List all possible solutions you (and others, if you collaborated) came up with. Step 3. Categorize & narrow. Group your list into themes or categories. Then choose 3 possible options that you believe are most viable. Step 4. Evaluate. For each of the 3 options, analyze the advantages and disadvantages. Submission fields: A. Reframed goal-oriented question (1–2 sentences). B. Brainstorm list (5+ items; bullet list). C. Three chosen options (bullets). D. Advantages and disadvantages (120–200 words, covering all 3 options).
answers: A. Reframed Goal-Oriented Question How might I create a clear reporting process with reminders and standards for my team so that all progress reports are complete and submitted by Friday 5 p.m. for on-time consolidation within the next four weeks? B. Brainstorm List Send automated reminder emails one day before the deadline. Create a shared checklist or tracker in Google Sheets. Standardize file naming and folder structure. Assign a rotating “report lead” each week to double-check submissions. Add report submission as a recurring task in the project management tool (e.g., Trello/Asana). Schedule a short 10-minute Friday afternoon check-in. Provide examples of properly completed reports for reference. Incentivize on-time submissions with recognition in team meetings. C. Three Chosen Options Automated reminder emails. Shared checklist/tracker in Google Sheets. Rotating “report lead” for accountability. D. Advantages and Disadvantages Automated reminders are easy to implement and reduce forgetfulness, ensuring that deadlines are top of mind. However, people may begin to ignore repetitive reminders if they become routine. A shared checklist in Google Sheets increases visibility for everyone and allows real-time tracking of progress, but it requires consistent updating and discipline from all team members. The rotating “report lead” adds accountability and distributes responsibility, encouraging more ownership of the process. The drawback is that it adds extra work for one person each week, which could cause resistance if workloads are already high. Together, these three options balance automation, transparency, and accountability, making them strong candidates for solving the reporting delay problem.

question: You’ve brainstormed and evaluated solutions. Now, before recommending your final choice, pause to anticipate emotional and interpersonal reactions—including your own. answers: A. Triggers Reflection One situation that triggers a negative reaction for me is when people dismiss a process improvement idea without giving it proper consideration. I also find it frustrating when team members consistently miss deadlines and don’t acknowledge the impact it has on others. Words like “this is unnecessary” or “we’ve always done it this way” can make me defensive because they suggest resistance to change. Additionally, when feedback is delivered in a harsh or dismissive tone, I sometimes take it personally, which can make me less open to collaboration in the moment. B. Potential Triggering Responses A colleague might say the reminder emails are “annoying spam.” Someone may resist the rotating lead role, claiming they are already too busy. C. Recommendation I recommend implementing automated reminder emails combined with a shared Google Sheets tracker to improve accountability and timeliness. This solution is lightweight, easy to implement, and minimizes additional workload, while providing clear visibility for both team members and managers. D. Feedback Strategy If I receive critical feedback, I will first pause and listen carefully without interrupting. I will ask clarifying questions to fully understand the concerns rather than reacting defensively. For example, if someone feels reminders are excessive, I could suggest adjusting frequency or customizing recipients. I will acknowledge valid points and show flexibility by adapting the solution while still keeping the overall goal in mind. By focusing on the shared objective—timely and accurate reporting—I can keep the discussion constructive and collaborative.

question: After scoring yourself, answer these questions: How did you score? Were you surprised by the results? How might you need to improve? What specific skills or behaviors need work? What things can you try to improve your feedback skills? List at least two strategies.
answers: After completing both self-assessments, I noticed that I generally scored “often” on areas like listening carefully, keeping emotions in check, and showing appreciation when giving or receiving feedback. I was not too surprised by these results, since I consciously try to remain calm and professional during feedback conversations. However, I did score myself “sometimes” in areas related to providing detailed, specific feedback and creating clear action plans. Similarly, when receiving feedback, I realized I sometimes become defensive if the message feels unfair or poorly delivered. This highlighted that while I am comfortable with the process, there are still areas for growth. The main areas where I need to improve include being more precise and constructive when giving feedback, rather than keeping my comments general. I also need to work on receiving difficult feedback without taking it personally, so I can focus on the content instead of the delivery. Strengthening these skills would make my feedback exchanges more effective and less emotionally charged. To improve, I plan to try two strategies. First, I will use the “SBI model” (Situation–Behavior–Impact) when giving feedback, because it encourages me to be concrete and objective while showing the effect of actions. Second, I will practice active reflection after receiving feedback by writing down what I heard, what I learned, and how I can apply it. This will help me shift my focus from reacting emotionally to using feedback as a growth tool. By applying these strategies consistently, I believe I can become more confident in both giving and receiving feedback, which will benefit my personal growth and strengthen collaboration within my team.

Managing SCARF Triggers: Identify one situation where you’ve experienced a SCARF trigger (Status, Certainty, Autonomy, Relatedness, Fairness). How could you manage that trigger differently in the future? Flexible Planning in a VUCA World: Provide one example of how you could plan multiple possible outcomes for a challenge at work or school. How does this approach help you stay adaptable? Small Goals & Measuring Progress: Set 1–2 small, measurable goals for cultivating adaptability or resilience. How will you track your progress?
answers: Control, Influence, Accept (CIA Framework) Control: My daily schedule and task prioritization. I can decide how to allocate my time and energy, so I placed this in the control category. Influence: Team deadlines. While I cannot fully control how others work, I can influence progress through reminders, check-ins, and offering support. Influence: Work environment communication. I cannot control every interaction, but I can influence tone and clarity through my own behavior. Accept: Organizational policy changes. These are outside of my control, so acceptance is the most constructive approach. Accept: Unexpected technical issues. I can only accept that they happen and respond calmly rather than resist. Adaptive and Resilient Behaviors I want to strengthen adaptive behavior in problem-solving by practicing reframing challenges into opportunities for learning. I will do this by asking myself, “What can I learn or try differently?” whenever I face a setback. For resilience, I want to practice recovery through consistent self-care routines, such as taking short breaks during stressful days and journaling weekly to reflect on lessons learned. Managing SCARF Triggers I often feel a fairness trigger when workload distribution seems uneven. Instead of reacting with frustration, I could manage it by calmly raising the issue, asking clarifying questions, and suggesting solutions that feel equitable. This would help me remain constructive while addressing the concern. Flexible Planning in a VUCA World For an upcoming group project, instead of creating a single rigid plan, I can map two possible paths: one if all members meet deadlines and another if delays occur. This contingency approach keeps me prepared and lowers stress, allowing me to adapt quickly without losing progress. question: Flexibility Employers and their employees need to react quickly to changing business conditions. Employers need employees who can change gears and adapt as required. ~Employment North Employers want to hire professionals who are flexible. Those who are stuck in their ways tend to be more difficult to work with than those who can go with the flow. Flexibility goes hand-in-hand with adaptability. ~Glassdoor

Enthusiasm for New Knowledge and Skills As businesses change, there is often a need to find out new information, expand knowledge and explore new ways of doing things. People with an interest in learning, and a willingness to pass it on to others, become invaluable. ~Employment North Most of us have worked with someone who hates to be bothered to learn new things. Whenever there is something new to learn, that person says, "Oh no, not something new! I hate having to change the way I do things." Managers want to hire people who like to learn. If you read in your spare time or follow courses online, say so!

Adaptability In some fields, a job is changing and evolving day-by-day. Employers want to hire adaptable professionals who can change with it. This may mean someone who can follow directions one-day and figure out their own direction the next. Or perhaps someone who can spend some days behind their desk and other days in the field, equally productive in both environments. ~Glassdoor

Self-Reliance Employers do not want to hire people who require hand-holding or constant praise in order to feel appreciated. They are looking for employees who can motivate themselves, figure out what needs to be done and then do it. Everyone appreciates a pat on the back from time-to-time, but it shouldn't be required to do your job well. ~Glassdoor

Know Their Strengths Employers are looking for people who know what they're good at. Instead of saying "I'm really good at Excel," you can say "I love Excel - and I love to teach other people the finer points of using Excel, like creating nested reports and macros. ~Forbes

answers: Effective Networking Habits From the list, two habits I already practice are taking initiative and showing authenticity. I often take the first step to reach out to colleagues, whether it’s introducing myself to a new team member or suggesting a meeting to collaborate. Authenticity is important to me because I believe people can sense when interactions are genuine, and I try to bring openness into conversations. Two habits I would like to improve are following up after the initial meeting and maintaining the connection. I sometimes fail to check back in with colleagues after the first interaction, which limits long-term relationship building. Strengthening these areas will help me create more sustainable and supportive connections. 5 Ways to Create Stronger Connections This week, I will focus on asking meaningful questions. Instead of limiting conversations to small talk, I will ask colleagues questions like “What project has been most interesting for you lately?” This approach will help me better understand their perspectives and build more authentic connections. Listening Skills Checklist My strongest skill is maintaining eye contact and minimizing distractions. Recently, during a team meeting, I closed my laptop and gave full attention to the presenter, which made the interaction more engaging. The skill I need to improve most is not interrupting. Last week, I cut into a colleague’s explanation because I thought I knew where they were going, and I realized afterward that it may have made them feel unheard. Practicing patience and waiting until they finish will strengthen my listening. Action Steps for Expanding Connections Inner circle: My current support group includes my manager, two teammates, and a mentor. I can show appreciation by sending a thank-you message highlighting specific ways they’ve helped me. 3 individuals to know better: (1) A new hire—I’ll invite them for coffee. (2) A senior colleague—I’ll ask for career advice. (3) A cross-functional teammate—I’ll check in on their current project. New network/event: I will attend an upcoming professional development webinar in my field. When challenges arise, I can lean on relationships for advice and encouragement instead of feeling isolated. Building stronger connections also increases adaptability, since I can learn new approaches from others, and resilience, since trust and support help me recover faster from setbacks.
